author: SteveL-MSFT
body: PowerShell currently only compiles a script block after it's run 32 times, we should allow scripts authors to tag script blocks where they choose to have compiled initially.

comments.author: BrucePay
comments.body: Compilation is expensive and consumes space. Doing it unnecessarily will slow everything down. So consider a set of modules all annotated to compile but only a subset are actually called. You end up taking the time/space hit from compiling unnecessarily. As was the case with the `register` keyword in C, the compiler can figure out low-level resource allocation better than the script author so I don't think this is a desirable thing long-term. Improving hotspot detection seems like a better place to invest resources.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @BrucePay compilation is expensive, but this would be opt-in by the user.  Perhaps consider it a hint than a directive.

comments.author: BrucePay
comments.body: @SteveL-MSFT history has shown this to be a bad idea (Java hotspot, V8, etc). People aren't good at flow analysis of significant code basis. Modern C compilers ignore `register` because it actively interferes with compiler register allocation i.e. it makes things worse. I expect that we would end up in a similar situation.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: I can accept that if such a capability was introduced, too many people would simply use it to compile their scripts which will introduce other problems.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: Users could use classes if want compilation. Another option is `Add-Type` to get critical fast code.

title: Introduce attribute to tag a script block as something that should be compiled
